Arcadia Quest is a fun and light "all-out-brawl" sort of game. You maneuver your clan of 4 heroes and attack monsters and other clans, while collecting items and gold.

By far the funnest part of the game is spending your hard-earned gold at the end of a particular quest to get improved gear. The gear is varied and remains exciting throughout the campaign.

The biggest down-side to the game is the amount of luck involved in attacking and defending. Every time you roll a critical, you get to roll the dice again, and if you get another one, you roll again, and again. Sometimes you can cause devastating damage just out of sheer luck, and this has turned off a lot of people who I have played with.

If you are OK with the possibility of dying frequently due to your lack of luck or due to the incredible luck of your opponents, then this game should be a worthy addition to your library.

Arcadia Quest is a PvP as good as you can get, with skirmished battles packing some of the most lovely miniatures you will ever saw.
The game is competitive, a lot, where each player chooses a team of 3 characters who will dispute the goals with the other teams: the one who completes a certain number of goals first wins the game.

 The rules in general are quite simple, on your turn you choose one of your characters, being able to move and / or make an attack. When attacking, you use one of your character's equipment (swords, bows, spells, etc.) and place a marker on the equipment, indicating that it can no longer be used until your team rests. This is the other option for your turn: when you rest you do nothing, but all the equipment of all your characters can be used again. And the game goes on like this, with each player activating one of his characters (or resting), and passing the turn to the next player. Combats are resolved with attack dice rolls against defense dice rolls. The attacker deals an amount of damage equal to the difference in these rolls, killing the defender if he runs out of life. The variety of equipments, mechanics like the characters respawn after dieing, the creatures battles, calcutalting your movements and the possibility of betrayal attacks (not to say the must of it) sumed up with the difference goals to the victory gives the game a good tactical aspect, easy to learn, not so much to master.

Arcadia is a full plate for fans of dungeon crawlers and medieval fantasy in general. Each game you will be able to play a different scenario, with board setup, monsters and your own objectives, in addition to being able to play these scenarios in sequence in the form of a campaign collecting more and more equipments. To sum up a simple and functional game and, mainly, fun, that only gets better and better with its expansions.

Initial Rating: 6.0 (August 2015)

In general Cool Mini or Not games are gorgeous and very well produced, however I have found that most of their games fell flat for me so my desire to play Arcadia Quest was very low. Most of my friends rave about the game so it was only a matter of time before they made me play it. I found the game to be better than expected, but still an ok game for me.

The rules are dead easy and the playtime varies from each scenario. 

As I wrote before, the game is GORGEOUS, the miniatures are very well done and that’s its best strength.

I love campaign games in which you level up your character and that’s the main appeal for me here, I will even play a whole a campaign to see if the game improves for me. On the other hand, I almost always dislike PvP games because they feel unfair (all against the current leader or the weakest person) and Arcadia Quest is no exception. What I liked about the game is that it isn’t all about PvP, you need to get other things done other than attack your friends and that’s why I can enjoy the game.

Some of the characters feel unbalanced BUT this doesn’t bothers me as much because you have a team of characters and the equipment can change the stats dramatically. 

The gameplay is a bit shallow and repetitive with obvious decisions most of the time. The fun comes from seeing what happens when you attack a monster or friend.

It has a high luck factor (a negative for me in a game of this length), I won the last game because I rolled lots of shields in 9 consecutive attacks (all against the leader), so I won purely by luck. If a player fails to kill a target but leave him wounded all other players will try to attack that target (the weakest player). The equipment can change this point but I feel tactics take a second seat behind luck on Arcadia Quest.

Bottom line, Arcadia Quest is an ok game for me. I will play if requested but with some reluctance. I won’t buy it. It is a great game for many of my friends but not my kind of game.

First play impressions: it seems like  a hybrid between Wizwar and a more tactical combat game. Not sure if it's not doing it really well, or if I'm not the target audience for that sort of game (I love Wizwar, and like Memoir).

I like this more than I had expected to. It is a very streamlined tactical combat game with leveling and a campaign system. It isn't breaking new ground by any means. However, it is a unique mix of mechanics and they are woven together very well. The rules are clear and there are just enough of them to hold the game together, there is no bloat here.

[b]What I liked:[/b]
-Elegant rules and clear goals
-Quick playtime that doesn't get bogged down
-Fun combos
-PvP combat is often not in your best interest, and players are incentivized to spread their attacks around.
-Exploding 6's mean that there is always a chance you can get off the attack you want, or the defense you need. This adds a lot of dramatic moments.

[b]What I disliked:[/b]
-Random! The dice, of course, but it's not limited to that, I actually think they handled the dice well. It's more the multi-player chaos. For example, when a wounded character is ripe for the picking. Since killing them is one third of the points needed to win this can be a huge boon to the person who is next in turn order after the character is injured.

-You often have little you can do on a turn. Goals are not easy to accomplish, and attempting one will often leave it easier for the next player to accomplish. Additionally, leaving yourself in a vulnerable position is very bad. This means you are likely to have a few turns where you accomplished very little. Or possibly a few where you helped others more than yourself.

-Some of the equipment cards are terrible. A card has to at least earn it's slot, with only 4 slots per character each card must be good enough to justify its place and there are a handful of cheap equipment cards that cannot do this. Sure they cost almost no coins, but they consume 1 slot which is an incredibly valuable resource so they need to be better.

-Keeping the same characters for the entire campaign is boring. Swapping one out after each game would be nice. There are a lot of characters, and campaigns are long (~10 hours), so seeing more characters would have been welcome.

-The tactical/strategic thinking in the game is hampered considerably by the random elements.

-The game is a race to 3 points, obtaining the third point ends the round immediately and there is no compensation for going last. The earlier you are in turn order the better off you are, it is blatantly obvious and the game does nothing to deal with this. Results are not extremely lopsided only because the random elements help to washout this bias. 

-Being the first one to attack a big baddie is often bad. You don't have a good chance to kill them and you simply set them up for someone else. This can create really awkward situations where nobody wants to act first.

-Winning the campaign is oddly ambiguous. Perhaps an attempt to keep all the players engaged in the outcome. 

[b]Final thoughts:[/b]
I can see the appeal, especially if you like direct player conflict in your games. The quick playtime is nice and takes the edge off of the random elements. There is a high fun factor if you play with the right group. It's probably the best game I've ever played in the genre, but with a few major drawbacks for me. I think a rework of the game as a coop would appeal to me more.
You need to be in fun-mode to enjoy this, but when you are, you are in for a treat.

Хочу познайомити вас з однією з улюблених іграшок в моїй колекції: Arcadia Quest.
В даній грі кожен гравець представляє гільдію з 3х героїв та навипередки з іншими гільдіями намагається перемогти злого Лорда Фанга з його приспішниками, паралельно нахапавши побільше бабла собі та накидавши побільше западла гільдіям суперників.
Фактично гра розрахована на проходження міні-кампанії з 6ти місій з прокачкою персонажів та мобів між ними. Можна і просто пройти одиничну місію, але тоді втрачається сенс в золотих монетах за вбивство монстрів та гільдійців суперників, а також в прокляттях за смерть ваших персонажів. Тому особисто я рекомендую все таки виділяти час і грати кампанію. Благо кожна місія легко проходиться за годинку.
Сам же ігролад доволі простий: в свій хід ви або обираєте і ативуєте одного зі своїх персонажів (можна того ж самого щоходу), або відпочиваєте. Якщо активуєте персонажа, то він може пройти певну відстань по карті та здійснити атаку чи підняти по дорозі якісь ніштяки або відкрити двері. Всі атаки здійснюються кастомними шестигранними кубиками, кількість яких визначається зброєю, яку використовує для атаки ваш персонаж. Також зброя задає символ на грані кубика, який зараховується як попадання. При атаці на зброю кладенться спец жетон, щоб відмітити, що до відпочинку цей герой уже не може її використовувати. Ціль же атаки після підрахунку попадань кидає кубики на захист і віднімає від суми попадань кількість викинутих на кубиках щитків. Все, що лишилось, зараховуються цілі, як рани. Якщо кількість ран перевищує рівень життя персонажа, то він непритомніє. Монстри ж в такому випажку забираються з поля і атакуючий отримує нагороду в вигдялі золотих монет, або цінного луту з деяких мобів. Якщо ж ви вибрали відпочинок, то всі ваші непритомні персонажі відновлюють свій рівень життя на повертаються на поле бою. Також з карток зброї скидаються всі жетони і ці картки знов можна використовувати для атак.
Отак хід за ходом гравці наминають один одному боки, доки хтось один не виконає 3 квести. Варто відзначити, що всі квести в грі діляться на 2 види: ПвЕ і ПвП. Перші - це різноманітні 'збери певні жетони', 'завали моба', 'пробіжи в таку-то локацію' і т.п. Другі ж зводяться до вбивства персонажів з ворожих гільдій. Для виграшу з трьох квестів один обовязково мусить бути типу ПвЕ, тому просто викошувати інших гравців не завжди вигідно, треба і монстрам приділити трошки уваги.
Як я уже згадував вище, між місіями гравці докуповують новий шмот за зароблене в місії золото, а дехто й отримує різноманітні прокляття за смерть свої персонажів. Це може бути, як блок слоту під зброю на наступну місію, так і зменшене стартове здоровя.
Окремо хочеться згадати компоненти гри. Тут CMON не зрадили собі і щедро насипали в коробку мініатюр та картону. Тайли карти хорошої якості з яркими артами, картки з цупкого картону. Мініатюрки же - просто шик. Стьобна фентезі-чібі стилістика з купою відсилок: тут вам і Леголас, і Лерой Дженкінс, і лицарі з піромантом Бобом та кроликом-людожером з Монті Пайтона, і король Леонідас, і навіть Девід Боуї в роді Короля Гоблінів. Такі мініатюри просто просяться в покрас. А враховуючи їх розмір і деталізацію - це чудовий плацдарм на повчитись 'макати міньки в фарбу'. А ще можна замінити картонні жетони на офіційні пластикові, а монети навіть на металеві. І в кращих традиціях CMON гра поставляється з пластиковими органайзерами для мініатюрок, щоб нічого не розліталось по коробці.
Підсумовуючи, перед нами фановий амерітреш в милій чібі-стилістиці з кастомізованими мапами та цілою горою крутих мініатюрок в кращих традиціях широковідомої в вузьких колах компанії CMON. Однозначно 10/10: Завжди отримую задоволення від гри в неї.

Arcadia Quest is a lot of fun.  The variety in character skills and the upgrades to your characters in the form of items are the best part about Arcadia Quest. The game works well as a competitive and at times semi-coop game.  Fighting each other, while still having to achieve PvE goals (and not being rewarded with coin for killing the same team more than once per scenario) makes the game feel focused.  Upgrades feel great.  The reward after a scenario, even if you did poorly, feels good.  There are always cheap, but still powerful items that you'll want to pick up even if you didn't get much gold during a scenario, while you might also be tempted to hate draft some expensive items to keep them from the guy who did really well that round.  The game is fairly simple -easy enough to play with children, but still meaty enough for a group of more hardcore gamers.  

 Some of the later items can extend the game by a bit too much (mainly items with re-rolls).  The first 3 scenarios of a 6 scenario campaign are usually incredibly fun, whilst the remaining ones tend to drag on a little longer and not feel quite as fun.  On one hand, it is awesome to get more items and see your power increase by rolling more and more dice.  On the other hand, that means later combat tends to take a lot longer.  The more dice part is great, the main negative is really just the constant and (by the end) high number of re-rolls that take place every time.  Counting the extra dice is fine, but re-rolling a bunch of times while being incredibly powerful and useful, just makes everything take a little too long in the last few scenarios.    

Overall, it's a very fun game.  It perhaps wears out it's welcome a little bit by the end, but the final scenario is still usually a lot of fun, vying for that final blow.  If someone looks like a runaway leader, then you might end up all vs 1 in that scenario, and that has been fun as well.  There are only really two negatives for me, the aforementioned # of re-rolls in later scenarios, and also just the fact that it is campaign-based.  Being campaign-based isn't a problem in itself, but it does mean that playing through the campaign will take ~10 hours or more.  The game does include a good save system and even a one-shot guide.  You could just pick a level and draft items and start out wherever/do one scenario and call that good.  It is a lot of fun seeing your characters upgrade over the course of a campaign though, so that's still the best way to play, just be aware that it'll take along time/several sessions most likely.

Awesome campaign skirmishing game, especially 4 player. Gorgeous components, particularly the minis. Has plenty of direct conflict between players, plus player-vs-environment missions. Mission system avoids king making and balances the scenarios in a neat way. Uses burst dice, which means plenty of luck involved, but mitigated throughout the campaign with item cards and character abilities.

Arena combat, multi-scenario campaign, persistent loot and powers, and buckets of dice.

Not to be taken at all seriously, and tons of fun as long as you don't.

Good:
There are a lot of tense moments when you are trying to roll a hit or defense as well as a lot of strategy in drafting characters, equipment, and deciding how you will accomplish the objectives while hindering your foes from completing them. For me this balance of luck and strategy is what makes the game extremely re-playable. 

The rules aren't too complex and the games end up with a lot of humorous bolstering, there are post game tales about the backstabbing/lucky kills, and there is a pretty good sense of satisfaction when you are able to pull off a win.

The high-quality components is icing on the cake, which makes this a game I would recommend to folks interested in competitive dungeon crawl style games. 

Bad:
It takes a while to set up a scenario. One game took longer to set everything up than it did for the game to finish. It does become quicker the more you play though.

I prefer playing this game as a campaign for building a group up instead of by one-off scenario. This makes it less likely to be played when not in a consistent game group. 

There are a lot of extras for this game and if you end up enjoying the game you will likely want them all. Unfortunately, many extras were kickstarter exclusives so are way over priced.

Characters are unbalanced, so you need to know this when going into a draft and be familiar with a variety of characters. This means new players can select an underdog team if you allow them to. When teaching the game I usually don't partake in the draft and provide insight on character's strengths and weaknesses.

Arcadia Quest is so much fun! The rulebook looks big and intimidating, but its mostly pictures and fluff, so the game is fun to play and easy to teach. Arcadia Quest is a great entry-point into getting other players together for a campaign-style game. However, unlike many other campaign games like Descent or Imperial Assault that are all-against-one or fully cooperative, this game is purely player-vs-player, and even has PVP specific quests to accomplish in order to win the game. When teaching the game to new players, it is very important to reiterate this point with them so no one feels "betrayed" because someone stole their kill or even killed them. 

The game can be quite random as all attacks are dependent on dice rolls, but the game is typically quick enough that it doesn't bother me. I can, however, understand that it isn't for everyone because of the luck aspect associated with these dice rolls. Often times, players may get screwed because someone else was able to land the final blow on a monster that you have been scratching away at, or your heavily-geared hero may be killed by another players scrub because of some lucky dice rolls. That stuff doesn't bother me much, and the ridiculousness of the game propels this game towards the top of my list of my favorite games.

That saying, it's an amazingly fun game if you go into it knowing this. Especially if your gaming group is willing to play the campaign where it really shines because of the upgrades you can do in between quests. People who will like it: People who like in your face games and funny cartoony fantasy and dice rolling.

People who won't like it: People who hate dice rolling or are expecting a dungeon crawl.

4. Typical for Eric Lang, there is a tendency for balance issues (ganging up, king making, runaway leader, logical elimination, etc.). Eric Lang's way of increasing interaction is to create situations that require players to constantly be vigilant for these balance issues and focus attention on preventing it. Fundamentally, it's a Player vs Player skirmish tactic game. Only the player doing the "coup de grace" gets the point and there are plenty of teleporters: everybody will be targeting the most wounded players. The modular board doesn't use to be big, you will be able to attack almost any target in a given turn.

That means the game has a very important random component: if the previous player misses several targets leaving them wounded, you will be on your way to victory. The strategic component is almost non-existant and tactic component is very light: you just need to recognize targets of oportunity when available and take them, and trying to make the most of your abilities and items.

The gameflow is quite good, the games are very short and this is very positive for a game that light-hearted. It's been designed to be played as a campaign mode, and while there's also secnarios that can be played separately, I strongly disagree with one rule: these scenarios require the players to complete 3 goals, and the game stops as soon as one player does so, and awards him with 5 extra points; completing these goals can take 5-6 turns, that means in a given round, several players are likely to complete the feat, but only the firs of them will collect the 5 points (usually, you get around 8-11 points). That concedes a huge advantage to the first players, making them much more likely to win and making it impossible for the last player. I usually don't comment rules here, but I found this issue so serious that I felt I should do it.

There are quite a few minis, Chibi style, and the quality of the components and the art is very good. I would say the price, €90, is quite high even for its quality, moreover for a game that light.

My favourite game to play with the family (me, wife, 8-year old son and 10-year old daughter), and I think it's their favourite game to play too. My son isn't always keen to play games and gets distracted easily when he does, but Arcadia Quest always keeps his attention and he'll usually want to play again as soon as a scenario is finished. 

It's not a deep game, it's not supposed to be. It's just pure fun. But there's still enough strategy to make it satisfying; enough luck to ensure that anyone can win. 

The campaign is a fantastic experience. Getting better loot to build up your characters is just so enjoyable, and everyone develops a strong connection with the members of their team. We hate having to say goodbye to them at the end of a campaign and pick a new bunch for the next one. But at the same time we also can't wait to draft characters again, with fresh, exciting ideas of who to put together to comprise our next party.

Every now and then, when we have to cooperate to bring down a big enemy in a PvE quest, I get a flashback to old-school World of Warcraft raids. None of the complexity, but all the thrill. It's a special board game that can come close to capturing that feeling, even for a moment.

Arcadia Quest is a competitive game, but it's easy to tone down the competitive aspect if you choose to, which makes it ideal for playing with children. You can focus on PvE quests and even give them a hand when necessary in completing their own quests. Then you can regret your benevolence when they mercilessly stab you in the back to complete their final PvP quest and win the game. Oh yes, I've been there.

Each level has a number of quests up, both quests that involve doing something special on the map, and quests that reward you for killing other player's characters. The first to three quest completed is the winner. After each level, players get the opportunity to spend the dollars they gained to buy new equipment which is drafted. I was worried going into this game that the player vs player element would feel too harsh, or that the curses you get after having a character would die would feel too punitive, but that hasn't been the case. In truth both these elements serve to balance the game, and add more strategy in terms of your action choices and targets. I love how in this game, the player to your right controls the monsters during your turn. It turns what could have been an ill-thought out AI into an invested party making the best choices for them, but not for you.

[thing=155068][/thing] is a fine game: simple rules and quite easy to understand - it is basically just move and attack, or attack then move. There are choices about who to attack, from where, with which weapon, but, overall, they are easy to make.

The rhythm is accelerated - turns are fast and downtime, even with 4p, doesn't bother. The quality of the components is great - the minis are well done and quite nice, going less for realism and more in the caricature/anime vibe, sometimes not the best choice, but I liked them.

The mechanics include quite a high amount of luck mixed with decisions and preparation - attacks can go wrong in dire moments, even great defenses can fail terribly; there is also the luck when grabbing items around the scenario, in the draft of items to purchase and in the curses, these last two in between scenarios. Still, the game does limits the upperhand of someone lucky by not allowing more than 3 items to be purchased at a time; thus even someone that got everything going on her way in a given scenario, won't truly break the bank.

Furthemore, the mechanics push towards the conflict between players - the Guilds (the teams of 3 heroes each player has) will fight among themselves, as 2 of the 3 goals needed to win a scenario can come from knocking out heroes of other players. Being in the receiving end of this isn't too bad - a simple rest action will make all your fallen heroes to return, maybe even in a better position, with all items ready for action. The problem of being KOed is to drop all carried items/treasures and the chance of receiving a tough curse in the next scenario. Yet, [thing=155068][/thing] is far from being Thunderdome - though fights among players will happen often, the goal isn't exterminated, nor simply battling other will give out a win. Still, the direct conflict is very present, so be warned.

My main issue with [thing=155068][/thing] is the type of chicken category of gameplay. Many bosses or strong enemies won't fall by a single hit, and often is necessary to beat one or more of them in order to reach a goal (or this be the goal). This tends to leave players going "vulture" on the others actions, trying to send in an hero in order to seize an opportunity to strike the final blow and get all the glory, even if doing almost nothing of the work. This can also happen by just waiting someone to kill an enemy and just walking past the other hero an reaching the goal spot sooner. And, yes, the situation is - maybe even more - valid to attack heroes that shed took damage; blood in the water will attract the others like insects to a lamp. Therefore, in many moments, players went a "you go" state in which no one wants to be the first to attack or advance, simply wanting to wait out to grab an opportunity not created by them. Even the players that want to go and attack, ponder - what if I don't do enough damage, or what if the counter attack hurts me too much? Against some of this there are blocking rules, but not always they will do the trick.

Sadly this gets wort the more we play - a gamer problem not truly in the spirit of a light battle game, I know, but is there and the game not only allows it, it often rewards it. Be aware and think if your group can handle this well.

The replay value is there, with different scenarios and heroes - but with 4 players, you will see all the items and use all heroes.

Overall, [thing=155068][/thing] entertains well - without much commitment nor deep thought (ideally): it is a light game of rolling dice, killing monsters and knocking out the others; with a campaing mode with upgrades coming from the purchase of gear and weapons. If you go for what the game purposes to be, you will be happy. If you simply want more depth and choices, there are better options elsewhere. Know thyself.

It's a silly romp where that's light on rules and heavy on conflict.  Really it plays like an Arena more than a dungeon crawl.  There's no where to hide and vendettas will grow.  Should be obvious, but if dice frustrate you at all then this game will also.  You have to be okay with odds swinging wildly.  You might roll 5 hits and think you've easily vanquished that hero with one hit point and then he pulls an insane string of defensive "crits" and ends up killing you next turn instead.  If you're fine with that and can laugh in the face of your own misfortune, then this game is devilishly fun.  The game is light, but the tactical decisions are there, you have to weigh your choices constantly and look ahead for potential traps for those unsuspecting heroes in other guilds.  Some turns you might just be moving to set up for a future turn, or passing completely to refresh your characters, the game keeps trucking along briskly.  

The charm comes heavily from the video game feel, it's exciting. The production is beautiful, it's all flash and pizzazz and unsuspected thrills.  The whole concept of building up heroes, and gearing up as you play through scenarios that really sells it for me.  Great fun!

I will say that if you just play a random one-off scenario and wrote the game off, you're  missing out.  I'd rate the one-off scenario experience a 7 or so, playing through a campaign is magic.

The score is subject to change as I have only played the first two scenarios of the campaign but I suspect it will stay about the same. The first scenario was a bit basic but the second one ramped it up a bit and I feel it will only get better (this is reflected in the score of 8/10 though).
The game comes into it's own with the campaign elements of upgrading your heroes and the overall theme is pleasant and enjoyable.

EDIT:
I have now finished the campaign.
I like that if I played another campaign it would be with different quests potentially. I really like the fact that you can make your own quests. I think for those that would spend the time to do this and have a good imagination, the game would seem without limits. It does require a lot of time to do this though. The other neat thing is the ability to upgrade your characters and the strategy of playing to your strengths.
Some negatives are I found the in game items (quest specific ones that you can use as soon as you collect them) to be a little lacklustre though (not the cards, but the tokens). I think more would be better.
Another is more just related to my own thoughts on dungeon crawlers in general. While Arcadia Quest doesn't suffer as much as certain other dungeon crawlers, it still has elements of it being pretty obvious what to do or try at any given moment which is slightly boring but it is just glimpses; the multiplayer competitive nature of the game keeps it from being an issue. It is still streets ahead of other dungeon crawlers I have played (in my opinion) because of that multiplayer nature. Another thing that is more related to some bad experiences I have had with dice and that is the potential for extreme luck swings with dice and tokens to make the game pretty one sided. The random tokens you get mean that it is possible to just keep getting bad things while the other player has gets the all good. But I guess with a game like this you just accept that and hopefully it's not too extreme either way. I guess another negative was (and this may be just a two player thing) that you only needed to complete two quests per scenario. Sometimes this led to the scenario wrapping up very quickly (I guess I feel too quickly) as you could complete both quests in one shot and then scenario over, just like that.
One final thought. I do like the idea of a Dungeon Master variant because one of my favourite mechanics of a dungeon crawler is not being able to see what's on the board until I have line of sight of said thing. More surprises to be had this way.
